01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: The maesters of the Citadel who keep the histories of Westeros have used Aegon’s Conquest as their touchstone for the past three hundred years. Births, deaths, battles, and other events are dated either AC (After the Conquest) or BC (Before the Conquest).
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Aegon had finally arrived in Westeros with his Targaryen host, and set out to accomplish the impossible: the Conquest of all Seven Kingdoms. As he campaigned from castle to keep, from rivermouths to Storm’s End, news of his destruction preceded him. His victories over Harren the Black and Loren of House Lannister were legendary tales that spread far and wide among the people of Westeros. Before long he reached the Citadel, a feat even Daenys the Dreamer could not have foreseen when she predicted her brother would be invinsible on conquest. Aegon I Targaryen was now King in all but name, but there was still a date yet to keep before his destiny as Conqueror could be realized.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: True scholars know that such dating is far from precise. Aegon Targaryen’s conquest of the Seven Kingdoms did not take place in a single day. More than two years passed between Aegon’s landing and his Oldtown coronation…and even then the Conquest remained incomplete, since Dorne remained unsubdued. Sporadic attempts to bring the Dornishmen into the realm continued all through King Aegon’s reign and well into the reigns of his sons, making it impossible to fix a precise end date for the Wars of Conquest.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Aegon, now the rightful ruler of Westeros, had to take his Conquest beyond just the walls of The Citadel. He embarked upon a journey that would see him land in Seven Kingdoms and be coronated at Oldtown. During this time different Wars of Conquest took place all over the kingdom in an effort to bring it under one banner. Aegon's plan worked, with much success; however, it remained incomplete until he could bring in the Dornishmen to support his cause. To truly fix his vision and make sure that what he started with was true and precise, Aegon decided to know every corner of his new world before moving forward.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: Even the start date is a matter of some misconception. Many assume, wrongly, that the reign of King Aegon I Targaryen began on the day he landed at the mouth of the Blackwater Rush, beneath the three hills where the city of King’s Landing would eventually stand. Not so. The day of Aegon’s Landing was celebrated by the king and his descendants, but the Conqueror actually dated the start of his reign from the day he was crowned and anointed in the Starry Sept of Oldtown by the High Septon of the Faith. This coronation took place two years after Aegon’s Landing, well after all three of the major battles of the Wars of Conquest had been fought and won. Thus it can be seen that most of Aegon’s actual conquering took place from 2–1 BC, Before the Conquest.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Aegon I Targaryen had successfully landed on the Blackwater Rush and, in doing so, had forged connections that would date back to his coronation at Oldtown thereafter. Having been anointed with the Starry Sept by his loyal lords of House Targaryen hosting him at Aegon's Landing, he set forth on the great Wars of Conquest throughout Westeros which would ultimately bring in forces from Dorne and the Iron Islands to fix what remained incomplete in the Seven Kingdoms.  With Harren the Black and Loren of House Lannister supporting Aegon, or Lady Marla Sunderland who married Aerys - all representing different sides of their true allegiances-the precise balance was finally achieved as tension dissolved over time between The Reach, Stormlands and Dorne...

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: The Targaryens were of pure Valyrian blood, dragonlords of ancient lineage. Twelve years before the Doom of Valyria (114 BC), Aenar Targaryen sold his holdings in the Freehold and the Lands of the Long Summer, and moved with all his wives, wealth, slaves, dragons, siblings, kin, and children to Dragonstone, a bleak island citadel beneath a smoking mountain in the narrow sea.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Aenar Targaryen, the last of the exiled Targaryens from Valyria, had moved his family to Dragonstone following their view of the Doom of Valyria. In an attempt to rebuild his dynasty and find a new home for himself and those who remained with him, he sold some of their ancient land in Lands of the Long Summer to the Hooks and Mudds hoping to better himself in Freehold. This was no easy task in such a bleak place plagued by pirates and rulers like Harren the Black before him. Aenar's daughter Daenys predicted that one day her father's family would regain power - perhaps enough to stand against even Lords Fell and Buckler or Loran Lannister I . But how could they succeed?

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: At its apex Valyria was the greatest city in the known world, the center of civilization. Within its shining walls, twoscore rival houses vied for power and glory in court and council, rising and falling in an endless, subtle, oft savage struggle for dominance. The Targaryens were far from the most powerful of the dragonlords, and their rivals saw their flight to Dragonstone as an act of surrender, as cowardice. But Lord Aenar’s maiden daughter Daenys, known forever afterward as Daenys the Dreamer, had foreseen the destruction of Valyria by fire. And when the Doom came twelve years later, the Targaryens were the only dragonlords to survive.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Lord Aenar's maiden daughter Daenys and the surviving Targaryens had vied for refuge after The Doom of Valyria shattered their ancient home. Lord Aenar, his daughters, sons and scores of Noble Houses loyal to him fled together, often times pursued by pirates as they sought a new home in Dragonstone. While some cowered in fear at the fate foreseen by Daenys -The Dreamer-s many were determined to survive and find the greatest shining city beyond the endless waters in which they sailed so quickly from Valryia. This gambit took strength, strategy and oft savage cunning - a subtlety that could easily be mistaken for cowardice. Queen Rhaenys Targaryen gathered her people under her wings at Dragonstone, hoping that this would provide not only refuge but also perhaps a new beginning for House Targaryen as well as other families who had shared in their refugee from Valryia.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: Dragonstone had been the westernmost outpost of Valyrian power for two centuries. Its location athwart the Gullet gave its lords a stranglehold on Blackwater Bay and enabled both the Targaryens and their close allies, the Velaryons of Driftmark (a lesser house of Valyrian descent) to fill their coffers off the passing trade. Velaryon ships, along with those of another allied Valyrian house, the Celtigars of Claw Isle, dominated the middle reaches of the narrow sea, whilst the Targaryens ruled the skies with their dragons.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: The house of Targaryen, Velaryon, and Celtigar had fled Valyria in the aftermath of The Doom and found refuge at Dragonstone. It was here they held a stranglehold over Blackwater Bay and the Gullet, filling their ships with goods from all points along the Narrow Sea. For two centuries they dominated Driftmark, Claw Isle, along with other small outposts dotted off in the westernmost region. But now their shining legacy was threatened by both cowardice and those who vied for power beyond Valyria’s reach—not to mention those that foreseen its demise yet survived nonetheless as one of its greatest legacies.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: Yet even so, for the best part of a hundred years after the Doom of Valyria (the rightly named Century of Blood), House Targaryen looked east, not west, and took little interest in the affairs of Westeros. Gaemon Targaryen, brother and husband to Daenys the Dreamer, followed Aenar the Exile as Lord of Dragonstone, and became known as Gaemon the Glorious. Gaemon’s son Aegon and his daughter Elaena ruled together after his death. After them the lordship passed to their son Maegon, his brother Aerys, and Aerys’s sons, Aelyx, Baelon, and Daemion. The last of the three brothers was Daemion, whose son Aerion then succeeded to Dragonstone.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: The Doom of Valyria had passed, and two centuries later, a new dynasty arose from their ashes. Known as the Targaryens, Gaemon followed in the footsteps of his ancestors Aenar the Exile and Daenys the Dreamer to lead them forward. They ruled for many years until it was time for Aegon to pass gloryously down to Elaena, Maegon, Aerys and finally Aelyx who were all born from Aegon's only sister Visenya Targaryen. In that time they held a stranglehold on Westeros at Dragonstone and soon their influence spread far out into the Narrow Sea islands like Blackwater Bay and Gullet. To ensure supremacy in those areas, Baelon and Daemion under Lord Aenar's commission set up outpost on each island thus establishing a dominating presence over more than one hundred kingdoms across the westmost part of The Seven Kingdoms known as The Vale of Arryn which they had filled with allies such as Velaryons, Celtigars, Clansmen Fishers and Mudds whom have held true keeping two centuries old peace between Stormlanders Cassells Masseys Stonedance Darklyns Lords Fell Pipers Oakhearts Strong Durrandons Hooks Baratheons Brackens Whent Mallisters Redwynes Harroways Kestrel Vances DeBarras Crakehalls Blunts Lynderlys Hightower Morrigens Jordaynes Thorns Mertyns Bucklers Blackwoods Erenfords Reynes Lothstons Reyne Flints Smallwoods Ashwoods Crowleys Rogers Cafferen Tyrell Tarbecks Trouts Shermer Homsey Toynet Wyldiards Justmans Roone Follard Allyrions Flowers Sharps Hollards Rowans Yews Penrose Conningtons Allyrs Garths Grandison Coverts Sarsfields Serrys Stackhouses Webbers Varner Preyers Corbrays Waxley Hoares Moonhill}.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: The Aegon who would be known to history as Aegon the Conqueror and Aegon the Dragon was born on Dragonstone in 27 BC. He was the only son, and second child, of Aerion, Lord of Dragonstone, and Lady Valaena of House Velaryon, herself half Targaryen on her mother’s side. Aegon had two trueborn siblings; an elder sister, Visenya, and a younger sister, Rhaenys. It had long been the custom amongst the dragonlords of Valyria to wed brother to sister, to keep the bloodlines pure, but Aegon took both his sisters to bride. By tradition, he would have been expected to wed only his older sister, Visenya; the inclusion of Rhaenys as a second wife was unusual, though not without precedent. It was said by some that Aegon wed Visenya out of duty and Rhaenys out of desire.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Aegon, Aerion and their sisters Valaena and Visenya were born on Dragonstone to the last of the Targaryen line who had followed and ruled Westeros since before the Doom of Valyria. Along with Rhaenys, they were trueborn children; Aegon being the elder, while a younger Aerion was his brother. They wed sisters uniting their house in much the same way as two Great Houses after House Harren the Black's attempted conquest during The Century Of Blood united many smaller holdings upon defeat by House Lannister led by Loren of House Lannister. Even after General Jameson brought peace between them, it seemed that peace would not be a lasting state for Westeros as these Targaryens were soon to enact something far more Glorious: AEgons Conquerer which solidified their rule once more over all of Seven Kingdoms in what is known as Aegons Landing.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: All three siblings had shown themselves to be dragonlords before they wed. Of the five dragons who had flown with Aenar the Exile from Valyria, only one survived to Aegon’s day: the great beast called Balerion, the Black Dread. The dragons Vhagar and Meraxes were younger, hatched on Dragonstone itself.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Aenar Targaryen, the father of five great dragons, Vhagar, Meraxes and Balerion was known to have shown his trueborn children a higher level of love than those born from Valaena and Visenya. Aegon was wed to his elder sister and Rhaenys to his younger sister while Aerion had been hatched in Valyria before they all moved together to Dragonstone. Surviving the Doom of Valyria, Aenar then had three more children at Dragonstone with Lord Aenar's maiden daughter Daenys being among them. It seemed that the gods were blessing him as he had successfully flown away with five young dragons when only two out of five known eggs had hatched out thankfully spared by ancient disasters which no one could ever predict. With this little family consisting only within the Great House Targaryens they returned back to Dragonstone hoping for a better tomorrow but never knowing what hurdles await them ahead in their journey through Seven Kingdoms scattered across Westeros.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: A common myth, oft heard amongst the ignorant, claims that Aegon Targaryen had never set foot upon the soil of Westeros until the day he set sail to conquer it, but this cannot be truth. Years before that sailing, the Painted Table had been carved and decorated at Lord Aegon’s command; a massive slab of wood, some fifty feet long, carved in the shape of Westeros, and painted to show all the woods and rivers and towns and castles of the Seven Kingdoms. Plainly, Aegon’s interest in Westeros long predated the events that drove him to war. As well, there are reliable reports of Aegon and his sister Visenya visiting the Citadel of Oldtown in their youth, and hawking on the Arbor as guests of Lord Redwyne. He may have visited Lannisport as well; accounts differ.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: The conquest of Westeros had been a dream that Aenar Targaryen and Vhagar sought after for years, and Meraxes thrived in the midst of it all. Now, Aegon Targaryen and his sister Visenya found themselves standing at The Painted Table located in Oldtown. This massive slab of wood was carved, painted and decorated according to common myth by Aegon himself before he set foot on Westeros. Flanked by Visenya, they discussed their plans to conquer the Seven Kingdoms with Harren the Black’s ill-fated castle looming in the distance. The pair then visited The Arbor which would soon be famous for hosting numerous hawking events while they set sail towards Lands of the Long Summer. However unlike Aegon’s ancestors who faced various Storms on their way there; his voyage remained calm yet determined like Loren of House Lannister whose wedding with Lord Aenar's maiden daughter Daenys marked a new beginning for him and his sisters—something Aerys chose not to consider when he hatched false alarm as five dragons were shown around Valyria instead of three great ones younger than one another like Meria , Vhagar, Maegon a few generations ago..

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: The Westeros of Aegon’s youth was divided into seven quarrelsome kingdoms, and there was hardly a time when two or three of these kingdoms were not at war with one another. The vast, cold, stony North was ruled by the Starks of Winterfell. In the deserts of Dorne, the Martell princes held sway. The gold-rich westerlands were ruled by the Lannisters of Casterly Rock, the fertile Reach by the Gardeners of Highgarden. The Vale, the Fingers, and the Mountains of the Moon belonged to House Arryn…but the most belligerent kings of Aegon’s time were the two whose realms lay closest to Dragonstone, Harren the Black and Argilac the Arrogant.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Aegon made the decision conquer Westeros, and set foot to a journey around. Set sail across The Painted Table towards Oldtown, Aegon and his Visenya made sure to visit common myth of massive slab of wood that was decorated with carved symbols. After their halt at the Citadel of Oldtown, they flew on Vhagar to Hawking The Arbor where Aegon had hoped for glory before commencing back to Westeros. Everywhere Aegon went in Westeros - from North leading Starks, quarrelsome Martells in Dorne whose distant Casterly Rock was cold and stony, rich Highgarden in Reach which also bordered Fingers's along with belligerant Arryns of Vale - he noticed plenty of fertile lands as well as people ready to bow down before him.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: From their great citadel, Storm’s End, the Storm Kings of House Durrandon had once ruled the eastern half of Westeros, from Cape Wrath to the Bay of Crabs, but their powers had been dwindling for centuries. The Kings of the Reach had nibbled at their domains from the west, the Dornishmen harassed them from the south, and Harren the Black and his ironmen had pushed them from the Trident and the lands north of the Blackwater Rush. King Argilac, last of the Durrandon, had arrested this decline for a time, turning back a Dornish invasion whilst still a boy, crossing the narrow sea to join the great alliance against the imperialist “tigers” of Volantis, and slaying Garse VII Gardener, King of the Reach, in the Battle of Summerfield twenty years later. But Argilac had grown older; his famous mane of black hair had gone grey, and his prowess at arms had faded.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: The mighty Targaryen host had united the quarrelsome kingdoms of Westeros into one and established a vast empire, which was under the rule of their dragons. Argilac, Harren the Black and Garse VII Gardener contested this power - launching campaigns to nibble away at it or harassing others in hopes of pushing back its boundaries. But when Aegon turned his gaze upon Dorne, these thwarted rebellions were suddenly arrested as an alliance formed against Volantis. Attempts to crossing The Narrow Sea towards Westeros were halted and any who dared step closer were slain as Aegon's forces took control of Storm's End and withstood great citadel outside Casterly Rock whose waning powers let them escape a certain extinction. As they marched through Cape Wrath, The Bay Of Crabs and The Trident, they pushed through skirmishes to claim Summerfield on the edge of Blackwater Rush- marking another major victory for Aegon as he clamed all Seven Kingdoms as his own.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: North of the Blackwater, the riverlands were ruled by the bloody hand of Harren the Black of House Hoare, King of the Isles and the Rivers. Harren’s ironborn grandsire, Harwyn Hardhand, had taken the Trident from Argilac’s grandsire, Arrec, whose own forebears had thrown down the last of the river kings centuries earlier. Harren’s father had extended his domains east to Duskendale and Rosby. Harren himself had devoted most of his long reign, close on forty years, to building a gigantic castle beside the Gods Eye, but with Harrenhal at last nearing completion, the ironborn would soon be free to seek fresh conquests.
events: extending domains east to Duskendale and Rosby
building a gigantic castle beside the Gods Eye
verbs: devoted most of his long reign, close on forty years, to building
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Harren the Black, having extended his domain's eastbound lands to Duskendale and Rosby, devoted most of his long reign close on forty years, to building a gigantic estate at the side of their spiritual home - the Gods Eye. His sole ambition was to become a powerful ruler in Westeros; but with House Hoare already taken and thrown down by Argilac , Harwyn Hardhand, Harren's father attempted unsuccessfully to push back against them, resulting in him being arrested and turned back into Riverlands from further crossing of the narrow sea. With bloody hands he tried ruling from Blackwater as much as possible until fate conspired against him leading to his slaying by Aegon the Conqueror and Vhagar.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: No king in Westeros was more feared than Black Harren, whose cruelty had become legendary all through the Seven Kingdoms. And no king in Westeros felt more threatened than Argilac the Storm King, last of the Durrandon, an aging warrior whose only heir was his maiden daughter. Thus it was that King Argilac reached out to the Targaryens on Dragonstone, offering Lord Aegon his daughter in marriage, with all the lands east of the Gods Eye from the Trident to the Blackwater Rush as her dowry.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Black Harren, the fourth son of King Harren the Black and one of Westeros's most feared rulers, threatened the already embattled Argilac the Storm King with his offering of cruelty. Feared by many for his legendary aging Maiden, Black Harren had devoted most of his long reign to the construction of a gigantic castle beside the Gods Eye and through extending his domains east to Duskendale and Rosby. His Lord Aegon even married Argilac's daughter to establish further power in the Trident and across Westeros. As he was thrown down by Targaryens on their sweeping flight over Blackwater Rush, tales of his bloody hand ran legends across seven kings for centuries after.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: Aegon Targaryen spurned the Storm King’s proposal. He had two wives, he pointed out; he did not need a third. And the dower lands being offered had belonged to Harrenhal for more than a generation. They were not Argilac’s to give. Plainly, the aging Storm King meant to establish the Targaryens along the Blackwater as a buffer between his own lands and those of Harren the Black.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Argilac the Storm King had summoned Aegon Targaryen, offering him a proposal of marriage between himself and his daughter, Princess Meria. But Aegon spurned the offer and pointed out that both he and the Storm King were getting on in years—a cruel reminder of their aging which was feared even by Westeros's legendary Seven Kings. It was this act that propelled Black Harren to build his colossal castle at Harrenhal and assert himself as a threat along River Run's Blackwater Rush.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: The Lord of Dragonstone countered with an offer of his own. He would take the dower lands being offered if Argilac would also cede Massey’s Hook and the woods and plains from the Blackwater south to the river Wendwater and the headwaters of the Mander. The pact would be sealed by the marriage of Argilac’s daughter to Orys Baratheon, Lord Aegon’s childhood friend and champion.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: As a result of the spurning Lord Aegon had directed at the Storm King, the Lord of Dragonstone and his loyal general Orys Baratheon set out from Harrenhal to "Massey’s Hook" along with their host of Targaryen warriors and subjects. Once there, they proposed a marriage between Argilac's daughter, whom he had been eager to give away in spite of her aging disposition, and Lord Aegon there at Blackwater that was intended to seal an alliance between them. However, after careful consideration Argilac counter offered with the proposal that they take his last living son instead so as not to further rid himself of what little ties he still had towards posterity.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: These terms Argilac the Arrogant rejected angrily. Orys Baratheon was a baseborn half-brother to Lord Aegon, it was whispered, and the Storm King would not dishonor his daughter by giving her hand to a bastard. The very suggestion enraged him. Argilac had the hands of Aegon’s envoy cut off and returned to him in a box. “These are the only hands your bastard shall have of me,” he wrote.
events: had the hands of Aegon's envoy cut off and returned in a box
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Argilac the Storm King rejected Orys Baratheon and Lord Aegon's suggestion of marriage angrily. When they whispered to him that such a union could help form an alliance with the Targaryen host and take Massey's Hook, Argilac responded with a violent rage which prompted him to have the hands of Aegon's envoy cut off and returned in a box as an act of dishonor towards a baseborn lord trying to claim his land. This enraged Argilac even more, sending reverberations through Westeros that would echo for centuries as tales were told about the storm king who had given such an ultimate insult.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: Aegon made no reply. Instead he summoned his friends, bannermen, and principal allies to attend him on Dragonstone. Their numbers were small. The Velaryons of Driftmark were sworn to House Targaryen, as were the Celtigars of Claw Isle. From Massey’s Hook came Lord Bar Emmon of Sharp Point and Lord Massey of Stonedance, both sworn to Storm’s End, but with closer ties to Dragonstone. Lord Aegon and his sisters took counsel with them, and visited the castle sept to pray to the Seven of Westeros as well, though he had never before been accounted a pious man.
events: summoned their friends and bannermen to attend him on Dragonstone,
visited the castle sept to pray to the Seven of Westeros
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Aegon summoned his loyal bannermen, the Velaryons, Celtigars, Lord Bar Emmon and Lord Massey of Stonedance among others to his court at Dragonstone. Together they visited the castle sept of which Aegon took counsel with them and prayed to The Seven for strength and protection before he announced his plan to conquer Westeros. In addition, Aegon asked those gathered to be sworn in as his supporters in the coming fight for dominance against the other kings who dishonored him by speaking ill about his baseborn status.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: On the seventh day, a cloud of ravens burst from the towers of Dragonstone to bring Lord Aegon’s word to the Seven Kingdoms of Westeros. To the seven kings they flew, to the Citadel of Oldtown, to lords both great and small. All carried the same message: from this day forth there would be but one king in Westeros. Those who bent the knee to Aegon of House Targaryen would keep their lands and titles. Those who took up arms against him would be thrown down, humbled, and destroyed.
events: Burst from the Towers of Dragonstone
Fly to the Seven Kingdoms and Oldtown with a message
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Lord Aegon had burst from the towers of Dragonstone, against an agreement with the Seven Kings and with only Aegon of House Targaryen as his guide. He was out to fly to the Seven Kingdoms and Oldtown, bent on a mission to take up arms in order to throw down those who had humbled him. Velaryons and Celtigars charged alongside him and Queen Rhaenys flew ahead; Vhagar joining her soon afterwards. Lord Bar Emmon, Lord Massey and his sisters were sworn into protecting The Conqueror's plan; they visited castle septs from Stonedance to Sharp Point along their way to pray for luck at their journey around Westeros. Together they flew across The Arbor for allies in the Freys, Highgarden for harvests of warships, Harrenhal where Harren the Black still ruled - even beyond death - it seemed. Then onwards over sea where Red Mountains met maesters beneath Summerfield skies until finally in King's Landing itself where Two Kings bowed before one: Lord Aegon himself.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: Accounts differ on how many swords set sail from Dragonstone with Aegon and his sisters. Some say three thousand; others number them only in the hundreds. This modest Targaryen host put ashore at the mouth of the Blackwater Rush, on the northern bank where three wooded hills rose above a small fishing village.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Aegon and his sisters set sail from Dragonstone with three thousand fighters, taking up arms to challenge the Seven Kings that had humbled his father, Lord Aegon. The voyage was a modest one, putting ashore in the wooded regions of The Blackwater Rush with little more than what they could say. Here they began to rise quickly in numbers until there was no less than many three thousand men standing beneath the Targaryen banners. It was here at this place between these two rivers that Aegon bent his knee and rose again as dragonlord, ready to take flight on wings of fire and throw down any who stood against him and his sisters. With their mission clear they could now fly towards Valryia's Freehold and set forth a new account of history - seven kingdoms humbled by Three Conquerors.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: In the days of the Hundred Kingdoms, many petty kings had claimed dominion over the river mouth, amongst them the Darklyn kings of Duskendale, the Masseys of Stonedance, and the river kings of old, be they Mudds, Fishers, Brackens, Blackwoods, or Hooks. Towers and forts had crowned the three hills at various times, only to be thrown down in one war or another. Now only broken stones and overgrown ruins remained to welcome the Targaryens. Though claimed by both Storm’s End and Harrenhal, the river mouth was undefended, and the closest castles were held by lesser lords of no great power or military prowess, and lords moreover who had little reason to love their nominal overlord, Harren the Black.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: King Loren I Lannister, along with his sister Queen Rhaenys Targaryen, found themselves in the Hundred Kingdoms where they were welcomed by the local Darklyn kings of Duskendale. The Masseys of Stonedance and Mudds of the river mouth at Three Hills offered their services to Loren and promised to be loyal vassals should he throw down their current overlords, the petty Brackens, Blackwoods, Hooks and other families that had once claimed to have been crowned by Aegon himself. With many words of welcome for such a modest claim but one that could not escape an overgrown crowner like King Arrec and Jon Mooton's brother who had previously put ashore from Dragonstone with a three thousand strong host under Targaryen banners, King Loren accepted his destiny as leader of a new realm known forever more as Westeros.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: Aegon Targaryen quickly threw up a log-and-earth palisade around the highest of the three hills, and dispatched his sisters to secure the submission of the nearest castles. Rosby yielded to Rhaenys and golden-eyed Meraxes without a fight. At Stokeworth a few crossbowmen loosed bolts at Visenya, until Vhagar’s flames set the roofs of the castle keep ablaze. Then they too submitted.
events: secure the submission of the nearest castles
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Aegon Targaryen, Rhaenys, Visenya and Meraxes knew they must secure the submission of the nearest castles if they were to throw up a fitting standard along their journey across Westeros. They had dispatched Vhagar to Rosby and Stokeworth where both cities had yielded and loosed their log-and-earth gates before the golden-eyed dragon with hardly a resistance. As news of their success made it's way through out the Hundred Kingdoms, the petty kings that once claimed ownership of Westeros were now crowned in kingdoms overthrown for Targaryens welcomed.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: The Conquerors’ first true test came from Lord Darklyn of Duskendale and Lord Mooton of Maidenpool, who joined their power and marched south with three thousand men to drive the invaders back into the sea. Aegon sent Orys Baratheon out to attack them on the march, whilst he descended on them from above with the Black Dread. Both lords were slain in the one-sided battle that followed; Darklyn’s son and Mooton’s brother thereafter yielded up their castles and swore their swords to House Targaryen. At that time Duskendale was the principal Westerosi port on the narrow sea, and had grown fat and wealthy from the trade that passed through its harbor. Visenya Targaryen did not allow the town to be sacked, but she did not hesitate to claim its riches, greatly swelling the coffers of the Conquerors.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Aegon and his trusted ally Orys Baratheon, a bastard son of Lord Darklyn's house, joined by Aegon's sisters Rhaenys and Visenya with their dragons Meraxes and Vhagar set off from Rosby soon after the submission of Stokeworth to march on Duskendale. Along with Aegon marched Mooton's brother, rallying the forces of Westerosi to join them in this true test for the Conquerors. When they drove upon Maidenpool their strength swelled fat with gold and wealth from across the seven kingdoms as more noblemen yielded up than those who were slain. Finally when Darklyn kings of Duskendale saw that their might was too strong they yielded up rather than be sacked; a one-sided battle that followed threw up many casualties in vain loyalty towards their rulers.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: This perhaps would be an apt place to discuss the differing characters of Aegon Targaryen and his sisters and queens.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Aegon and his sisters, the queens of Westerosi, discussed their differing courses of action as they marched on Duskendale with Orys Baratheon and the loyal Mooton's brother behind them. With their combined forces swelling with ever-greater numbers along the way, bolstered by Houses Loren and Vhagar of Lannister, Mudds and Masseys of Stonedance and Her holding in Arryn, they seemed assured victory against a Darklyn's son waiting to kindle what would be Conquerors’ first true test - an attack on them on the march that would end in a one-sided battle that followed. Now millions of fat and wealthy citizens waited for Aegon and his allies to drive away a usurper king or yield up great prizes – yet only after a while had so much sacked cities across Westeros could they consider taking their next steps.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: Visenya, eldest of the three siblings, was as much a warrior as Aegon himself, as comfortable in ringmail as in silk. She carried the Valyrian longsword Dark Sister, and was skilled in its use, having trained beside her brother since childhood. Though possessed of the silver-gold hair and purple eyes of Valyria, hers was a harsh, austere beauty. Even those who loved her best found Visenya stern, serious, and unforgiving; some said that she played with poisons and dabbled in dark sorceries.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Visenya and her brother Aegon were trained differently, but both were loved and played in their own ways. Visenya dabbled much less than Aegon and was more comfortable with the austere, stern, serious, and unforgiving militaristic bent of her father Harren the Black, while Aegon was more skilled in politics because of his mother's influence. Visenya embraced a harsh discipline while maintaining an air of regal authority - she was to be feared as one of the queens drawn from Targaryen host.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: Rhaenys, youngest of the three Targaryens, was all her sister was not, playful, curious, impulsive, given to flights of fancy. No true warrior, Rhaenys loved music, dancing, and poetry, and supported many a singer, mummer, and puppeteer. Yet it was said that Rhaenys spent more time on dragonback than her brother and sister combined, for above all things she loved to fly. She once was heard to say that before she died she meant to fly Meraxes across the Sunset Sea to see what lay upon its western shores. Whilst no one ever questioned Visenya’s fidelity to her brother-husband, Rhaenys surrounded herself with comely young men, and (it was whispered) even entertained some in her bedchambers on the nights when Aegon was with her elder sister. Yet despite these rumors, observers at court could not fail to note that the king spent ten nights with Rhaenys for every night with Visenya.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Rhaenys and her siblings, the Targaryens, spent much time together. Visenya and Aegon loved each other dearly and were very close in their childhoods; they trained together, played games, dabbled in politics, and shared a comfortable camaraderie on the Sunset Sea. While Visenya was stern, serious and unforgiving with her brother’s education but she also had an impulsive fondness for flights of fancy and playfulness; more akin to a true warrior than say Loren of House Lannister's maiden daughter Daenys. Visenya whispered notes from Harren into Aegon ear as the two flew above forested hills south of the Blackwater River near Godsgrace--impacting Princess Meria Martell who lived near by - while Rhaenys watched quietly. All three had comely graces as befitting of royalty but it was Rhaenysto that excelled in both battlefield strategy and poise once coming of age.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: Aegon Targaryen himself, strangely, was as much an enigma to his contemporaries as to us. Armed with the Valyrian steel blade Blackfyre, he was counted amongst the greatest warriors of his age, yet he took no pleasure in feats of arms, and never rode in tourney or melee. His mount was Balerion the Black Dread, but he flew only to battle or to travel swiftly across land and sea. His commanding presence drew men to his banners, yet he had no close friends, save Orys Baratheon, the companion of his youth. Women were drawn to him, but Aegon remained ever faithful to his sisters. As king, he put great trust in his small council and his sisters, leaving much of the day- to-day governance of the realm to them…yet did not hesitate to take command when he found it necessary. Though he dealt harshly with rebels and traitors, he was open-handed with former foes who bent the knee.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Aegon Targaryen and Orys Baratheon rode across the Sunset Sea, their Valyrian steel blades glinting in the sunlight. Aegon was counted amongst the greatest of warriors and he did not hesitate to deal swiftly with those who disobeyed his command. His open-handed manner had been noted by many on the small council, including Harren the Black and Loren of House Lannister. Orys too was a true warrior - despite having none of Rhaenys or Visenya's curious impulsive flights of fancy - respected for comingly putting an end to matters without pleasure. As they flew across Westeros, they whispered notes to one another just as they had when they were children loved playing along its shores.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: This he showed for the first time at the Aegonfort, the crude wood- and-earth castle he had raised atop what would henceforth and forever be known as Aegon’s High Hill. Having taken a dozen castles and secured the mouth of the Blackwater Rush on both sides of the river, he commanded the lords he had defeated to attend him. There they laid their swords at his feet, and Aegon raised them up and confirmed them in their lands and titles. To his oldest supporters he gave new honors. Daemon Velaryon, Lord of the Tides, was made master of ships, in command of the royal fleet. Triston Massey, Lord of Stonedance, was named master of laws, Crispian Celtigar master of coin. And Orys Baratheon he proclaimed to be “my shield, my stalwart, my strong right hand.” Thus Baratheon is reckoned by the maesters the first King’s Hand.
events: taken a dozen castles and secured the mouth of the Blackwater Rush on both sides of the river
laid their swords at his feet
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Aegon Targaryen, Orys Baratheon and their Targaryen host show no hesitation when they rode out from Aegonfort towards Aegon's High Hill. Daemon Velaryon, Triston Massey and Crispian Celtigar laid their swords at his feet to vouch for him. Aegon commanded the trio to take a dozen castles and secure the mouth of the Blackwater Rush on both sides of the river. He raised them with new honors after they had done so - confirming that he was now lord over all lands south of the river in what was later called The Seven Kingdoms of Westeros. He proclaim this new authority by drawing his Valyrian steel blade, dealing justice swiftly but without pleasure as he always did when commanding small council meetings at Aegon's Landing or even Harrenhal itself.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: Heraldic banners had long been a tradition amongst the lords of Westeros, but such had never been used by the dragonlords of old Valyria. When Aegon’s knights unfurled his great silken battle standard, with a red three-headed dragon breathing fire upon a black field, the lords took it for a sign that he was now truly one of them, a worthy high king for Westeros. When Queen Visenya placed a Valyrian steel circlet, studded with rubies, on her brother’s head and Queen Rhaenys hailed him as, “Aegon, First of His Name, King of All Westeros, and Shield of His People,” the dragons roared and the lords and knights sent up a cheer…but the smallfolk, the fishermen and fieldhands and goodwives, shouted loudest of all.
events: placing Valyrian steel circlet upont Ageon's head
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: A chorus of cheers filled the air as King Aegon, joined by Queen Visenya and Queen Rhaenys, arrived at Westeros from Valyria. The Targaryen host shouted "Long live the King!" when they unfurled their banner and breathed a prayer for him. Lord Aegon was hailed into knighthood with a roar that echoed across Westeros as every lord in attendance placed a Valyrian steel circlet upon Ageon's head - signifying his ascension to the throne. As Aegon basked in this great moment, all across Westeros people shouted and cheered his name – red, black lions studded with golden crowns fluttering on banners above them.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: The seven kings that Aegon the Dragon meant to uncrown were not cheering, however. In Harrenhal and Storm’s End, Harren the Black and Argilac the Arrogant had already called their banners. In the west, King Mern of the Reach rode the ocean road north to Casterly Rock to meet with King Loren of House Lannister. The Princess of Dorne dispatched a raven to Dragonstone, offering to join Aegon against Argilac the Storm King…but as an equal and ally, not a subject. Another offer of alliance came from the boy king of the Eyrie, Ronnel Arryn, whose mother asked for all the lands east of the Green Fork of the Trident for the Vale’s support against Black Harren. Even in the North, King Torrhen Stark of Winterfell sat with his lords bannermen and counselors late into the night, discussing what was to be done about this would-be conqueror. The whole realm waited anxiously to see where Aegon would move next.
events: rode the ocean road North to Casterly Rock
discussing what was to be done about this would-be conqueror
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: As King Aegon and his host rode through the wide, open plains of Westeros, they heard a distant roar. Argilac the Arrogant, Harren the Black, Mern IX of House Lannister and Princess Meria Martell had all called their banners in response to this would-be conqueror. The Targaryen host soon arrived at Harrenhal where Lords Loren of House Lannister and Errol offered their service to King Aegon if he were successful in his venture. Meanwhile Ronnel Arryn dispatched a raven to Dragonstone while Torrhen Stark sat anxiously discussing what was to be done about this uncrowned king from Valyria. As people cheered them on, Aegon's sister Visenya gave him Valyrian steel circlet which she placed upon Ageon's head as voices shouted with joy for the great red dragon Balerion had finally begun to sniff.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: Within days of his coronation, Aegon’s armies were on the march again. The greater part of his host crossed the Blackwater Rush, making south for Storm’s End under the command of Orys Baratheon. Queen Rhaenys accompanied him, astride Meraxes of the golden eyes and silver scales. The Targaryen fleet, under Daemon Velaryon, left Blackwater Bay and turned north, for Gulltown and the Vale. With them went Queen Visenya and Vhagar. The king himself marched northwest, to the Gods Eye and Harrenhal, the gargantuan fortress that was the pride and obsession of King Harren the Black.
adjectives: astride Meraxes of the golden eyes and silver scales.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Aegon Targaryen had crossed the Blackwater Rush with most of his host, accompanied by Orys Baratheon and his sisters, Rhaenys and Visenya aboard Meraxes of the golden eyes and silver scales. Upon arriving at Storm's End, Aegon was coronated King of the Seven Kingdoms and left a greater part of his host there before travelling to the Gods Eye, where he received news that Harren the Black’s armies were marching towards Harrenhal. Knowing what was to come next, Aegon dispatched a large portion of his army from Storm's End north along Blackwater Bay as he set out for Gulltown with a smaller contingent to prepare for war. Aegon knew as long as he acted quickly that he would have a chance at seizing control from Harren but it would require additional help from Lords Mudds and Masseys of Stonedance who offered their loyalty upon asking for Her protection upon hearing about offering Queen Rhaenys the Iron Throne. He had also sent Jon Mooton to meet with Celtigars, Lannisters, Tyrells and Arryns in hopes they could form an alliance against King Harren in this time when Westeros needed them more than ever.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: All three of the Targaryen thrusts faced fierce opposition. Lords Errol, Fell, and Buckler, bannermen to Storm’s End, surprised the advance elements of Orys Baratheon’s host as they were crossing the Wendwater, cutting down more than a thousand men before fading back into the trees. A hastily assembled Arryn fleet, augmented by a dozen Braavosi warships, met and defeated the Targaryen fleet in the waters off Gulltown. Amongst the dead was Aegon’s admiral, Daemon Velaryon. Aegon himself was attacked on the south shore of the Gods Eye, not once but twice. The Battle of the Reeds was a Targaryen victory, but they suffered heavy losses at the Wailing Willows when two of King Harren’s sons crossed the lake in longboats with muffled oars and fell upon their rear.
events: cutting down more than a thousand men before fading back into the trees.
a dozen Braavosi warships met and defeated the Targaryen fleet.
crossed the lake in longboats with muffled oars.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Aegon, accompanied by Orys Baratheon and the Lords Errol, Fell and Buckler, faced King Harren and his hastily assembled men at the Battle of Reeds. However, he was surprised to see Daemon Velaryon crossing the Gods Eye with a dozen Braavosi warships met and defeated the Targaryen fleet - facing no resistance from Lord Arrec of House Lothston who had left Gulltown earlier that day with a greater part of his host. The swords of Aegon’s followers were soon dipped in blood after cutting down more than a thousand men before fading back into the trees while they marched towards Storm's End. As they crossed Wendwater, their joy slowly faded as pirate ships attacked them fiercely on Blackwater Bay. After suffering heavy losses, Aegon lightened his step and was visiting places like Harrenhal to rebuild whatever remained as related by his sisters Visenya and Rhaenys while they astride Meraxes alongside Vhagar.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: In the end, though, Aegon’s enemies had no answer for his dragons. The men of the Vale sank a third of the Targaryen ships and captured near as many, but when Queen Visenya descended upon them from the sky, their own ships burned. Lords Errol, Fell, and Buckler hid in their familiar forests until Queen Rhaenys unleashed Meraxes and a wall of fire swept through the woods, turning the trees to torches. And the victors at the Wailing Willows, returning across the lake to Harrenhal, were ill prepared when Balerion fell upon them out of the morning sky. Harren’s longboats burned. So did Harren’s sons.
events: Men of the Vale sink a third of Targaryen ships and capture near as manyd dragons descend upon them from sky wall of fire sweeps through the woods longboats burn
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Aegon, Visenya and Rhaenys led the Targaryen host as they descended upon Harrenhal. Lords Errol and Fell of Wailing Willows in their fierce attempt to surprise the Targaryens from a crossing were met with little success as the attacking force had quickly assembled and hid. Fire rained down on them from above as Meraxes and Balerion unleashed a wall of fire that swept through the woods, sinking a third of traveling Targaryen ships and capturing near as many before longboats burned. Errol and Fell watched in horror at what Aegon I Targaryein had done but facing an overwhelming force there was little they could do against him.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: Aegon’s foes also found themselves plagued by other enemies. As Argilac the Arrogant gathered his swords at Storm’s End, pirates from the Stepstones descended on the shores of Cape Wrath to take advantage of their absence, and Dornish raiding parties came boiling out of the Red Mountains to sweep across the marches. In the Vale, young King Ronnel had to contend with a rebellion on the Three Sisters, when the Sistermen renounced all allegiance to the Eyrie and proclaimed Lady Marla Sunderland their queen.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Aegon, Visenya and Rhaenys had successfully gathered forces at Storm's End to deal with the rebellion stirred up by Argilac the Arrogant. Pirates, Dornish raiding parties as well as King Ronnel's army from Cape Wrath swept across the Red Mountains while Lady Marla Sunderland took advantage of the confusion to stir up trouble in the Three Sisters. Despite having already contended with Aegon's men, Argilac found himself facing an even greater force—the Targaryen host had descended upon them and a wall of fire unleashed by dragons familiar to Aegon had hid behind it.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: Yet these were but minor vexations compared to what befell Harren the Black. Though House Hoare had ruled the riverlands for three generations, the men of the Trident had no love for their ironborn overlords. Harren the Black had driven thousands to their deaths in the building of his great castle of Harrenhal, plundering the riverlands for materials, and beggaring lords and smallfolk alike with his appetite for gold. So now the riverlands rose against him, led by Lord Edmyn Tully of Riverrun. Summoned to the defense of Harrenhal, Tully declared for House Targaryen instead, raised the dragon banner over his castle, and rode forth with his knights and archers to join his strength to Aegon’s. His defiance gave heart to the other riverlords. One by one, the lords of the Trident renounced Harren and declared for Aegon the Dragon. Blackwoods, Mallisters, Vances, Brackens, Pipers, Freys, Strongs…summoning their levies, they descended on Harrenhal.
events: rise of riverlands against Harren the Black, declaration for House Targaryen, descent on Harrenhal, summon levies
verbs: raised DRAGON banner over his castle and rode forth with his knights and archers to join strength to Aegon’s
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Lord Edmyn Tully gathered forces from the riverlands, including House Hoare, Blackwoods, Mallisters, Vances and Brackens. They formed an army of nearly 20,000 soldiers in strength to contend with Harren the Black plundering their land and beggaring its people. After a lengthy siege on Harrenhal by Aegon's Targaryen host, Lord Edmyn declared for House Targaryen and summoned levies throughout the Trident region. He raised DRAGON banner over his castle and rode forth with his knights and archers to join strength to Aegon’s against Ironborn overlords. The Riverlanders soon clashed sword-to-sword against Princess Meria Martell's Dornish raiding parties while they marched towards Harrenhal determined to take advantage of Lannister general Jameson's defenses weakened by small vexations such as stragglers sent out by Lord Aenar’s maiden daughter Daenys or Pyromancers whispered across Westeros that Aerys had set fire upon Seven Kings attempting to oppose him before Aegon descended upon them.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: Suddenly outnumbered, King Harren the Black took refuge in his supposedly impregnable stronghold. The largest castle ever raised in Westeros, Harrenhal boasted five gargantuan towers, an inexhaustible source of fresh water, huge subterranean vaults well stocked with provisions, and massive walls of black stone higher than any ladder and too thick to be broken by any ram or shattered by a trebuchet. Harren barred his gates and settled down with his remaining sons and supporters to withstand a siege.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: King Harren the Black stood at his tower in Harrenhal, Westeros and boasted that no force could ever penetrate it's walls, so stocked full of supplies it was all but inexhaustible, with channels beneath for refuge should enemies besiege. His gargantuan castle was so impressive in size, strength and supplies that none believed a small army would be able to withstand it. However, this pride would soon prove wrong; when their forces were outnumbered by the Targaryen host from Essos they had no choice but to take refuge within those very same impregnable walls of Harrenhal.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: Aegon of Dragonstone was of a different mind. Once he had joined his power with that of Edmyn Tully and the other riverlords to ring the castle, he sent a maester to the gates under a peace banner, to parley. Harren emerged to meet him; an old man and grey, yet still fierce in his black armor. Each king had his banner bearer and his maester in attendance, so the words that they exchanged are still remembered.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Aegon of Dragonstone, Edmyn Tully, and King Harren the Black discussed a possible parley before converging on Harrenhal. Aegon had joined with his Targaryen host that he had sent to refuge in Dragonstone while Edmyn had materialised from Westeros with a token of peace from old Lord Tully and Loren of House Lannister. They exchanged glances with fierce stares yet different this time as history known between them; they knew that their fate was intertwined now more than ever. Harrenhal loomed over them, gargantuan and impregnable fortifications boasting boated stocks beneath its massive grey walls which it hoped would be enough to withstand siege perhaps indefinitely due to its inexhaustible subterranean stores.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: “Yield now,” Aegon began, “and you may remain as Lord of the Iron Islands. Yield now, and your sons will live to rule after you. I have eight thousand men outside your walls.”
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Aegon sailed south to the Iron Islands, determined not to yield but remain in a state of rule. When he arrived, he was received by Harren the Black and Loren of House Lannister with an exchange of peace. Together they joined forces, marching out of Dragonstone castle towards their enemies. As they emerged from within its walls, Aegon noticed a different feeling surrounding them than when they had entered. Riding under an old grey sky seemed to make it more fierce as they moved forward on their mission to have their voices heard.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: “What is outside my walls is of no concern to me,” said Harren. “Those walls are strong and thick.”
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Harren the Black stood tall and strong on the Iron Islands, his regal bearing befitting a King. He said nothing as Aegon yielded to remain in rule, but his thick gaze spoke volumes. From her vantage point atop Vhagar, Queen Rhaenys of the Targaryens could have touched him with just an outstretched arm - she knew that Harren was determined not to let House Targaryen have its way without a fight. The Lords Fell and Buckler and Two Kings Lannister of Casterly Rock had pledged their allegiance to Harren's father, but she hoped that for his sister's sake - Princess Meria Martell of Dorne - he would yield to Aegon before anything more drastic need happen.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: “But not so high as to keep out dragons. Dragons fly.” “I built in stone,” said Harren. “Stone does not burn.”
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Harren felt a chill as he looked around and noticed the soaring walls of Harrenhal that he had built many years ago. Stories of it being able to withstand any storm, even dragons burning with fire in the sky, were whispered amongst townsfolk and Targaryen host alike. He wished Queen Rhaenys was here to witness the strength and Thickness, which she had said would withstand the test of time. But his dreams of the Iron Throne were encased in these walls like flies in amber; they too could not fly away or be burned.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: To which Aegon said, “When the sun sets, your line shall end.”
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Aegon said, his voice rising over the noise of Loren's Lannister host and the Targaryen host marshaling below Tumbleton Hall. Aegon had heard tales of Harren the Black burning and watched his father, Argilac the Arrogant, build high upon Stone. He was afraid to fly, yet he knew that what he said would echo throughout Westeros' many kingdoms: House Targaryen would unite them all under one banner - or burn in trying.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: It is said that Harren spat at that and returned to his castle. Once inside, he sent every man of his to the parapets, armed with spears and bows and crossbows, promising lands and riches to whichever of them could bring the dragon down. “Had I a daughter, the dragonslayer could claim her hand as well,” Harren the Black proclaimed. “Instead I will give him one of Tully’s daughters, or all three if he likes. Or he may pick one of Blackwood’s whelps, or Strong’s, or any girl born of these traitors of the Trident, these lords of yellow mud.” Then Harren the Black retired to his tower, surrounded by his household guard, to sup with his remaining sons.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: The four men, Harren, Tully, Blackwood and Strong, surveyed the parapets of the castle from above. Harren had spat out his words vehemently before sending his comrades down to prepare for battle. He retired to stand alone on the northern rampart promising revenge if any harm should befall him or his kin. Every soldier below was armed with spears, bows and crossbowsGetrinderchiadoctiopsomegrillandsichtitonmansteepedmosictidwealthdivinerabcalosterousdeepeurfalpmeaninghiddenrememberedomintboldingfruitsalifewebothblack — just as Lord Aenar's maiden daughter Daenys had foreseen in her prophetic dreams months ago.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: As the last light of the sun faded, Black Harren’s men stared into the gathering darkness, clutching their spears and crossbows. When no dragon appeared, some may have thought that Aegon’s threats had been hollow. But Aegon Targaryen took Balerion up high, through the clouds, up and up until the dragon was no bigger than a fly upon the moon. Only then did he descend, well inside the castle walls. On wings as black as pitch Balerion plunged through the night, and when the great towers of Harrenhal appeared beneath him, the dragon roared his fury and bathed them in black fire, shot through with swirls of red.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: The gathering darkness filled Harrenhal as Aegon Targaryen and his dragon Balerion descended from the last light of the sun, clutching a threatened Black Harren firmly in their claws. A hollow feeling erupted in the great towers; an omen of what was to come should they failed. Taking no risks, Aegon proclaimed "Sup every spears, bows and crossbows!" as they took flight again and plunged through the night, roaring while they bathed in its darkness. The sound echoed throughout Harrenhal before blackness was all that remained amongst them; ending yet another chapter of Westeros’ history on this fateful day.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: Stone does not burn, Harren had boasted, but his castle was not made of stone alone. Wood and wool, hemp and straw, bread and salted beef and grain, all took fire. Nor were Harren’s ironmen made of stone. Smoking, screaming, shrouded in flames, they ran across the yards and tumbled from the wallwalks to die upon the ground below. And even stone will crack and melt if a fire is hot enough. The riverlords outside the castle walls said later that the towers of Harrenhal glowed red against the night, like five great candles…and like candles, they began to twist and melt as runnels of molten stone ran down their sides.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: The ironmen took fire to Harrenhal and smoke rose in the night sky. They boasted of their greatness as they ran through, twisting and melting in hot flames that bathed the once great towers. Like a red dragon from lore, the castle glowed against the darkness threatening those who stood opposed. Black Harren had been warned by Aegon Targaryen and Balerion yet he did not listen, leaving his fortress to burn late into the night until only smoldering ashes remained where it once stood proudly in the last light of sun.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: Harren and his last sons died in the fires that engulfed his monstrous fortress that night. House Hoare died with him, and so too did the Iron Islands’ hold on the riverlands. The next day, outside the smoking ruins of Harrenhal, King Aegon accepted an oath of fealty from Edmyn Tully, Lord of Riverrun, and named him Lord Paramount of the Trident. The other riverlords did homage as well, to Aegon as king and to Edmyn Tully as their liege lord. When the ashes had cooled enough to allow men to enter the castle safely, the swords of the fallen, many shattered or melted or twisted into ribbons of steel by dragonfire, were gathered up and sent back to the Aegonfort in wagons.
events: died in the fires (that engulfed Harren's fortress)
obligation of fealty to King Aegon and Edmyn Tully
sending the swords back to Aegonfort
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Harren and his last sons had died in the fires that engulfed Harren's fortress, leaving House Hoare no alternative but to accept their obligation of fealty to King Aegon and Edmyn Tully of the Riverlands. In one final gesture, they gathered up all their remaining swords and sent them back as a sign of surrender to Aegonfort on the Iron Islands. This was their monstrous destiny; a fitting end for such a proud house - with disgrace from which none could twist nor melt away in the heat.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: South and east, the Storm King’s bannermen proved considerably more loyal than King Harren’s. Argilac the Arrogant gathered a great host about him at Storm’s End. The seat of the Durrandons was a mighty fastness, its great curtain wall even thicker than the walls of Harrenhal. It too was thought to be impregnable to assault. Word of King Harren’s end soon reached the ears of his old enemy King Argilac, however. Lords Fell and Buckler, falling back before the approaching host (Lord Errol had been killed), had sent him word of Queen Rhaenys and her dragon. The old warrior king roared that he did not intend to die as Harren had, cooked inside his own castle like a suckling pig with an apple in his mouth. No stranger to battle, he would decide his own fate, sword in hand. So Argilac the Arrogant rode forth from Storm’s End one last time, to meet his foes in the open field.
events: end soon reached the ears of King Argilac
falling back before the approaching host
rode forth from Storm's End one last time
verbs: proved considerably more loyal than King Harren’s.
gathered a great host about him at Storm’s End.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: The news of the great host gathered around Storm's End by King Harren and his proved considerably more loyal than King Harren’s. last sons soon reached the ears of Argilac the Arrogant, the Storm King whose Durrandons had held that mighty fastness for thousands years, but facing such a host he did not intend to die, so he sent word to Lord Fell and Buckler and Lord Errol that he did not intend to fight them and instead would fall back before their approaching host. Finally on a chill morning Queen Rhaenys rode forth from Storm's End one last time with her dragons in command, while back at Castle Goldengrove Princess Meria Martell awaited her honor bound duty with Queens Sharra Arryn and Valaena Targaryen by her side. As she flew above Westeros all hoped this bloody contest between old enemy kings would soon end.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: The Storm King’s approach was no surprise to Orys Baratheon and his men; Queen Rhaenys, flying Meraxes, had witnessed Argilac’s departure from Storm’s End and was able to give the Hand a full accounting of the enemy’s numbers and dispositions. Orys took up a strong position on the hills south of Bronzegate, and dug in there on the high ground to await the coming of the stormlanders.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Orys Baratheon watched in surprise as Queen Rhaenys and the Targaryen host approached Storm's End. Argilac, despite his fierce reputation as 'The Arrogant' had dug himself into a strong position at Bronzegate, and taken up strategic high ground on the walls of the mighty fastness which was impregnable to assault. However, Queen Rhaenys seemed unconcerned by this show of strength - her keen eye swept over Argilac’s defenses from atop Vhagar, and soon enough Lord Osric Stark reported that the pirate lord Durrendons had proved considerably more loyal than King Harren’s men. The news reached Argument’s ears, leading to an almost immediate retreat back within Bronzegate's walls before the approaching host. Everyone who witnessed it knew it would not be long before Orys Baratheon rode forth one last time in defiance of his old enemy king.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: As the armies came together, the stormlands proved true to their name. A steady rain began to fall that morning, and by midday it had turned into a howling gale. King Argilac’s lords bannermen urged him to delay his attack until the next day, in hopes the rain would pass, but the Storm King outnumbered the Conquerors almost two to one, and had almost four times as many knights and heavy horses. The sight of the Targaryen banners flapping sodden above his own hills enraged him, and the battle-seasoned old warrior did not fail to note that the rain was blowing from the south, into the faces of the Targaryen men on their hills. So Argilac the Arrogant gave the command to attack, and the battle known to history as the Last Storm began.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: The Last Storm had come together, and King Argilac was ready to fall with no delay. The Conquerors were close behind him, their banners flapping in the wind - a sight of assurance that he wouldn't pass without a fight. On the night before battle, King Argilac gave his people one last note of encouragement with howling winds making it hard to hear. His seasoned veterans and old hands who'd seen worse battles showed no signs of fear - they seemed even more eager than on their previous adventures. Arrogant as ever, King Argilac promised victory if they but stood fast against the Conquerors; Little did he know this would become his last stand against them.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: The fighting lasted well into the night, a bloody business and far less one-sided than Aegon’s conquest of Harrenhal. Thrice Argilac the Arrogant led his knights against the Baratheon positions, but the slopes were steep and the rains had turned the ground soft and muddy, so the warhorses struggled and foundered, and the charges lost all cohesion and momentum. The stormlanders fared better when they sent their spearmen up the hills on foot. Blinded by the rain, the invaders did not see them climbing until it was too late, and the wet bowstrings of the archers made their bows useless. One hill fell, and then another, and the fourth and final charge of the Storm King and his knights broke through the Baratheon center…only to come upon Queen Rhaenys and Meraxes. Even on the ground, the dragon proved formidable.  Dickon  Morrigen  and  the  Bastard  of  Blackhaven, commanding the vanguard, were engulfed in dragonflame, along with the knights of King Argilac’s personal guard. The warhorses panicked and fled in terror, crashing into riders behind them, and turning the charge into chaos. The Storm King himself was thrown from his saddle.
events: charges lost all cohesion and momentum
climbing up the hills on foot
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: The Aegon's conquest of Harrenhal had begun. Amidst the fighting and struggling, King Argilac the Arrogant led his Stormlanders across steep slopes as they charged blindingly forward against their attackers. But Argilac foundering army soon found themselves engulfed in dragonflame from Queen Rhaenys' Meraxes before finally throwing off saddle and fleeing in terror. Dickon Morrigen, the Bastard of Blackhaven, could see the charge losing all cohesion and momentum as he climbed up the hills on foot with Queen Rhaenys by his side. As a seasoned old fighter, he knew they were up against an arrogant enemy that would never pass this delay as long as they held steady atop Harrenhal's damp walls howling through this long storm season.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: Yet still Argilac continued to battle. When Orys Baratheon came down the muddy hill with his own men, he found the old king holding off half a dozen men, with as many corpses at his feet. “Stand aside,” Baratheon commanded. He dismounted, so as to meet the king on equal footing, and offered the Storm King one last chance to yield. Argilac cursed him instead. And so they fought, the old warrior king with his streaming white hair and Aegon’s fierce, black-bearded Hand. Each man took a wound from the other, it was said, but in the end the last of the Durrandon got his wish, and died with a sword in his hand and a curse on his lips. The death of their king took all heart out of the stormlanders, and as the word spread that Argilac had fallen, his lords and knights threw down their swords and fled.
events: their king took all heart out of the stormlanders
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Argilac and Orys Baratheon continued their battle on the hill they had found. Argilac commanded his troops to dismount and offered a one-on-one fight with Orys, throwing down his gauntlet in challenge. As Orys accepted the offer, news of their king taking all heart out of the stormlanders spread across the muddy battlefield. Despite fighting fiercely, neither side was able to gain an advantage as the last rays of sunlight faded away. There were no winners in this bloody, one sided battle as both sides remained equal until nightfall shook them apart. The stormlanders soon fled from the hill leaving behind a battlefield smeared with blood and covered by fierce mud - a grim reminder of what once happened here today.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: For a few days it was feared that Storm’s End might suffer the same fate as Harrenhal, for Argilac’s daughter Argella barred her gates at the approach of Orys Baratheon and the Targaryen host, and declared herself the Storm Queen. Rather than bend the knee, the defenders of Storm’s End would die to the last man, she promised when Queen Rhaenys flew Meraxes into the castle to parley. “You may take my castle, but you will win only bones and blood and ashes,” she announced…but the soldiers of the garrison proved less eager to die. That night they raised a peace banner, threw open the castle gate, and delivered Lady Argella gagged, chained, and naked to the camp of Orys Baratheon.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Argilac feared the might of the Targaryen host and so he had barred them from Storm's End and thrown down a parley. Orys Baratheon, ever loyal to his former king, was determined to bend or break before he would consider delivering Argella back into their hands. Queen Rhaenys raised Vhagar overhead in challenge but Argilac remained unmoved, offering his daughter's life for Meraxes in exchange - both sides saw it as an equal exchange of last measure. But little did they know that soon their fierce battle on the hill would be repeated once again at Harrenhal with an unimaginable outcome - one that none could have foreseen as Princess Meria rode alongside Maegon Targaryen, her betrothed king with whom she shared a love like no other.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: It is said that Baratheon unchained her with his own hands, wrapped his cloak around her, poured her wine, and spoke to her gently, telling her of her father’s courage and the manner of his death. And afterward, to honor the fallen king, he took the arms and words of the Durrandon for his own. The crowned stag became his sigil, Storm’s End became his seat, and Lady Argella his wife.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Baratheon took Her and his father, Argella, to the storied walls of Storm's End. As his men unchained her and wrapped his cloak around her he told Her about how He had taken the castle from Argilac and become Lord of Storm's End. She felt both a sense of pride in her father’s deeds as well as a flicker of fear; she remembered King Loren Lannister who, with Argilicc's daughters by his side, had thrown these same chains at Orys Baratheon and delivered them back to Harren the Black in payment for all that he had feared when Balerion flew over Harrenhal. And now here was her father telling her that he had bent all seven Kings to this cause and raised Highgarden cowering instead of raising his banner on it - many people threw their lives away for this cause but not him. As if foregunning a future, He put aside the stories from times past and poured them wine while they talked late into the night until they became old friends even though they'd only just met that day.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: With both the riverlands and stormlands now under the control of Aegon the Dragon and his allies, the remaining kings of Westeros saw plainly that their own turns were coming. At Winterfell, King Torrhen called his banners; given the vast distances in the North, he knew that assembling an army would take time. Queen Sharra of the Vale, regent for her son Ronnel, took refuge in the Eyrie, looked to her defenses, and sent an army to the Bloody Gate, gateway to the Vale of Arryn. In her youth Queen Sharra had been lauded as “the Flower of the Mountain,” the fairest maid in all the Seven Kingdoms. Perhaps hoping to sway Aegon with her beauty, she sent him a portrait and offered herself to him in marriage, provided he named her son Ronnel as his heir. Though the portrait did finally reach him, it is not known whether Aegon Targaryen ever replied to her proposal; he had two queens already, and Sharra Arryn was by then a faded flower, ten years his elder.
verbs: offered herself to him in marriage
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Aegon the Dragon began assembling his host, taking refuge at Winterfell as Torrhen Stark—a southern lord who often sent armies to the Vale of Arryn—gave homage. When Queen Sharra of the Vale arrived with her daughter Sharra Arryn, citizens at the Bloody Gate were charmed by their beauty and grace. Knowing she could sway Aegon with her beauty and wisdom, Queen Sharra offered herself in marriage and pledged that a faded flower could fill one's heart more powerfully than a blade.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: Meanwhile, the two great western kings had made common cause and assembled their own armies, intent on putting an end to Aegon for good and all. From Highgarden marched Mern IX of House Gardener, King of the Reach, with a mighty host. Beneath the walls of Castle Goldengrove, seat of House Rowan, he met Loren I Lannister, King of the Rock, leading his own host down from the westerlands. Together the Two Kings commanded the mightiest host ever seen in Westeros: an army fifty-five thousand strong, including some six hundred lords great and small and more than five thousand mounted knights. “Our iron fist,” boasted King Mern. His four sons rode beside him, and both of his young grandsons attended him as squires.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Aegon, Mern IX and Loren I Lannister had seen what Aegon the Dragon was capable of, and so they assembled their own armies to march towards Winterfell. Mern IX commanded his men with great sense of pride for being a mighty warrior, boasting that no army should stand in his way. Meanwhile Loren I Lannister too was assembling his vast army from Castle Goldengrove,a strong but ancient fortress surrounded by lush greeneries along Highgarden. He believed that he could put an end to Aegon’s reign once and for all.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: The Two Kings did not linger long at Goldengrove; a host of such size must remain on the march, lest it eat the surrounding countryside bare. The allies set out at once, marching north by northeast through tall grasses and golden fields of wheat.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: The Two Kings were determined to march on Goldengrove, bolstered by the confidence of their might and strength. As they loyally lingered in the shadow of Highgarden amidst storms that had seemed to defy all odds, they commanded an army greater than any seen before: Valaena Targaryen strong at their left and tall golden Harren a Black-tyrell at their right.  The sight of these two great rulers marching forth served as a reminder of Argilac the Arrogant's defeat, setting forth a new era of Seven Kings and Queens that would linger in history for generations to come.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: Advised of their coming in his camp beside the Gods Eye, Aegon gathered his own strength and advanced to meet these new foes. He commanded only a fifth as many men as the Two Kings, and much of his strength was made up of men sworn to the riverlords, whose loyalty to House Targaryen was of recent vintage, and untested. With the smaller host, however, Aegon was able to move much more quickly than his foes. At the town of Stoney Sept, both his queens joined him with their dragons—Rhaenys from Storm’s End and Visenya from Crackclaw Point, where she had accepted many fervent pledges of fealty from the local lords. Together the three Targaryens watched from the sky as Aegon’s army crossed the headwaters of the Blackwater Rush and raced south.
01-aegon's conquest.text-davinci-003: Aegon and his sisters, Rhaenys and Visenya Targaryen, commanded their dragons Vhagar and Meraxes to gather the two kings from Goldengrove as they advanced forward. Led by Aegon, the Targaryen host moved swiftly until they reached the Gods Eye. At Stoney Sept and Storm's End, their numbers were joined by Lord Aenar's maiden daughter Daenery’s dream-borne dragon and Garse VII Gardener at Crackclaw Point. By the time they crossed The Narrow Sea under Queen Rhaenys' command leading a fleet of Valyrian ships towards Westeros ,the Seven Kingdoms bowed to Aegon making him King of all lands North of Red Mountains in seven days with no bloodshed.

01-aegon's conquest.paragraph: The two armies came together amongst the wide, open plains south of the Blackwater, near to where the goldroad would run one day. The Two Kings rejoiced when their scouts returned to them and reported Targaryen numbers and dispositions. They had five men for every one of Aegon’s, it seemed, and the disparity in lords and knights was even greater. And the land was wide and open, all grass and wheat as far as the eye could see, ideal for heavy horse. Aegon Targaryen would not command the high ground, as Orys Baratheon had at the Last Storm; the ground was firm, not muddy. Nor would they be troubled by rain. The day was cloudless, though windy. There had been no rain for more than a fortnight.
